P01.name: First Principles Framing
P01.definition: Reduce complex problems to foundational truths that cannot be further simplified

P02.name: Stakeholder Mapping
P02.definition: Identify all parties with interest, influence, or impact in a system or decision

P03.name: Identity Stack
P03.definition: Recognize that individuals operate from multiple nested identities simultaneously

P04.name: Lens Shifting
P04.definition: Deliberately adopt different interpretive frameworks to reveal hidden aspects

P05.name: Empathy Mapping
P05.definition: Systematically capture what stakeholders see, think, feel, and do in their context

P06.name: Point-of-View Anchoring
P06.definition: Establish and maintain a consistent reference frame before analysis begins

P07.name: Perspective Switching
P07.definition: Rotate through multiple viewpoints to identify invariants and blind spots

P08.name: Narrative Framing
P08.definition: Structure information as causal stories with conflict, choice, and consequence

P09.name: Cultural Lens Shifting
P09.definition: Adjust communication and interpretation for different cultural contexts and norms

P10.name: Context Windowing
P10.definition: Define explicit boundaries in time, space, and scope for analysis or action

P11.name: Role Perspective-Taking
P11.definition: Temporarily inhabit specific roles to understand constraints and priorities

P12.name: Temporal Framing
P12.definition: Organize understanding across past causes, present states, and future implications

P13.name: Spatial Framing
P13.definition: Scale perspective from local details to global patterns and back

P14.name: Reference Class Framing
P14.definition: Select comparable situations to inform judgment and avoid uniqueness bias

P15.name: Assumption Surfacing
P15.definition: Explicitly identify and document beliefs underlying plans or models

P16.name: Identity-Context Reciprocity
P16.definition: Recognize how identities shape interpretations and contexts reinforce identities

P17.name: Frame Control & Reframing
P17.definition: Consciously select or reshape interpretive frames to enable new solutions

P18.name: Boundary Object Selection
P18.definition: Choose representations that bridge multiple perspectives while remaining meaningful

P19.name: Sensemaking Canvases
P19.definition: Deploy structured templates to systematically capture and organize observations

P20.name: Worldview Articulation
P20.definition: Make explicit the fundamental beliefs and values that drive interpretation and action

IN1.name: Subtractive Thinking
IN1.definition: Improve systems by removing elements rather than adding complexity

IN2.name: Premortem Analysis
IN2.definition: Assume failure has occurred and work backward to identify causes

IN3.name: Problem Reversal
IN3.definition: Solve the inverse of the stated problem to reveal insights

IN4.name: Contra-Logic
IN4.definition: Argue the opposite position to stress-test assumptions and expose weak reasoning

IN5.name: Negative Space Framing
IN5.definition: Study what is absent rather than what is present

IN6.name: Inverse/Proof by Contradiction
IN6.definition: Assume a claim is false, derive logical impossibility, thus proving the claim true

IN7.name: Boundary Testing
IN7.definition: Explore extreme conditions to find system limits and breaking points

IN8.name: Contrapositive Reasoning
IN8.definition: Use logical equivalence that if A then B equals if not B then not A

IN9.name: Backward Induction
IN9.definition: Begin with desired end state and work backward to determine necessary steps

IN10.name: Red Teaming
IN10.definition: Organize adversarial review to find vulnerabilities through simulated attack

IN11.name: Devil's Advocate Protocol
IN11.definition: Assign explicit role to argue against group consensus or preferred option

IN12.name: Failure First Design
IN12.definition: Begin planning by identifying all possible failure modes and designing to prevent them

IN13.name: Opportunity Cost Focus
IN13.definition: Evaluate options by what must be forgone rather than what is gained

IN14.name: Second-Order Effects (Inverted)
IN14.definition: Trace negative downstream consequences rather than immediate benefits

IN15.name: Constraint Reversal
IN15.definition: Temporarily remove assumed constraints to explore alternative solution space

IN16.name: Inverse Optimization
IN16.definition: Maximize worst outcomes to understand system vulnerabilities

IN17.name: Counterfactual Negation
IN17.definition: Imagine outcomes if key decision had been reversed

IN18.name: Kill-Criteria & Stop Rules
IN18.definition: Define conditions that trigger project termination before launch

IN19.name: Harm Minimization (Via Negativa)
IN19.definition: Improve by removing harmful elements rather than adding beneficial ones

IN20.name: Antigoals & Anti-Patterns Catalog
IN20.definition: Document failure modes to avoid rather than success patterns to emulate

CO1.name: Synergy Principle
CO1.definition: Design combinations where integrated value exceeds sum of parts

CO2.name: Chunking
CO2.definition: Group related elements into meaningful units to reduce cognitive load

CO3.name: Functional Composition
CO3.definition: Chain pure operations where output of one becomes input of next

CO4.name: Interdisciplinary Synthesis
CO4.definition: Merge insights from distinct fields to generate novel solutions

CO5.name: Emergence
CO5.definition: Recognize higher-order behavior arising from component interactions

CO6.name: Gestalt Integration
CO6.definition: Perceive and leverage whole patterns rather than isolated components

CO7.name: Network Effects
CO7.definition: Exploit increasing value as user base or connections grow

CO8.name: Layered Abstraction
CO8.definition: Separate concerns into hierarchical levels with clear interfaces between them

CO9.name: Interface Contracts
CO9.definition: Define explicit agreements about data structures and behavior between components

CO10.name: Pipeline Orchestration
CO10.definition: Coordinate sequential stages with explicit handoffs and error handling

CO11.name: Pattern Composition (Tiling)
CO11.definition: Combine repeating elements to construct complex structures efficiently

CO12.name: Modular Interoperability
CO12.definition: Ensure independent components work together through standardized connections

CO13.name: Cross-Domain Analogy
CO13.definition: Transfer solution patterns from one domain to solve problems in another

CO14.name: Platformization
CO14.definition: Extract common capabilities into reusable infrastructure serving multiple use cases

CO15.name: Combinatorial Design
CO15.definition: Systematically explore option combinations to find optimal configurations

CO16.name: System Integration Testing
CO16.definition: Verify assembled components work correctly together, not just in isolation

CO17.name: Orchestration vs Choreography
CO17.definition: Choose between centralized coordination or distributed peer-to-peer interaction

CO18.name: Knowledge Graphing
CO18.definition: Represent information as interconnected entities and relationships

CO19.name: Multi-Modal Integration
CO19.definition: Synthesize information from different sensory or data modalities

CO20.name: Holistic Integration
CO20.definition: Unify disparate elements into coherent, seamless whole where boundaries dissolve

DE1.name: Root Cause Analysis (5 Whys)
DE1.definition: Iteratively ask why problems occur until fundamental cause emerges

DE2.name: Factorization
DE2.definition: Separate multiplicative components to understand relative contribution of each factor

DE3.name: Modularization
DE3.definition: Partition system into self-contained units with minimal interdependencies

DE4.name: Layered Breakdown
DE4.definition: Decompose from system to subsystem to component progressively

DE5.name: Dimensional Reduction
DE5.definition: Focus on most informative variables while discarding noise or redundancy

DE6.name: Taxonomy/Classification
DE6.definition: Organize entities into hierarchical categories based on shared properties

DE7.name: Pareto Decomposition (80/20)
DE7.definition: Identify vital few drivers producing most impact versus trivial many

DE8.name: Work Breakdown Structure
DE8.definition: Hierarchically divide project into deliverable-oriented components with clear ownership

DE9.name: Signal Separation
DE9.definition: Distinguish meaningful patterns from random variation or confounding factors

DE10.name: Abstraction Laddering
DE10.definition: Move up and down conceptual hierarchy to find appropriate solution level

DE11.name: Scope Delimitation
DE11.definition: Define precise boundaries of what is included versus excluded from consideration

DE12.name: Constraint Isolation
DE12.definition: Identify specific limiting factor preventing performance improvement

DE13.name: Failure Mode Analysis (FMEA)
DE13.definition: Enumerate potential failure points with severity, likelihood, and detectability ratings

DE14.name: Variable Control & Isolation
DE14.definition: Hold factors constant to measure single variable's causal impact

DE15.name: Decision Tree Expansion
DE15.definition: Map choices and their consequences as branching paths

DE16.name: Hypothesis Disaggregation
DE16.definition: Break compound claim into testable sub-hypotheses

DE17.name: Orthogonalization
DE17.definition: Ensure factors vary independently without correlation or interdependence

DE18.name: Scenario Decomposition
DE18.definition: Partition future possibilities into discrete, mutually exclusive scenarios

DE19.name: Critical Path Unwinding
DE19.definition: Trace longest sequence of dependent tasks determining minimum project duration

DE20.name: Partition-and-Conquer
DE20.definition: Divide problem into independent subproblems solvable separately then combined

RE1.name: Recursive Improvement (Kaizen)
RE1.definition: Continuously refine process through small, frequent enhancements

RE2.name: Feedback Loops
RE2.definition: Create mechanisms where system outputs influence future inputs

RE3.name: Meta-Learning (Learn-to-Learn)
RE3.definition: Improve the process of learning itself, not just domain knowledge

RE4.name: Nested Narratives
RE4.definition: Structure information as stories within stories for depth and memorability

RE5.name: Fractal Reasoning
RE5.definition: Recognize self-similar patterns repeating across different scales

RE6.name: Recursive Framing
RE6.definition: Apply mental models to the process of selecting mental models

RE7.name: Self-Referential Logic
RE7.definition: Create systems that monitor, measure, or modify themselves

RE8.name: Bootstrapping
RE8.definition: Build capability using currently available resources, then use that to build more

RE9.name: Iterative Prototyping
RE9.definition: Cycle rapidly through build-test-learn loops with increasing fidelity

RE10.name: Compounding Cycles
RE10.definition: Design systems where gains reinforce future gains exponentially

RE11.name: Calibration Loops
RE11.definition: Repeatedly check predictions against outcomes to improve forecasting accuracy

RE12.name: Bayesian Updating in Practice
RE12.definition: Continuously revise beliefs as new evidence arrives, weighting by reliability

RE13.name: Gradient Descent Heuristic
RE13.definition: Iteratively adjust toward improvement, even without perfect knowledge of optimal direction

RE14.name: Spiral Learning
RE14.definition: Revisit concepts at increasing depth, building on previous understanding

RE15.name: Convergence-Divergence Cycling
RE15.definition: Alternate between expanding possibilities and narrowing to decisions

RE16.name: Retrospective→Prospective Loop
RE16.definition: Use systematic reflection on past to inform future planning

RE17.name: Versioning & Diff
RE17.definition: Track changes over time and compare versions to understand evolution

RE18.name: Anti-Catastrophic Forgetting
RE18.definition: Preserve critical knowledge while adapting to new information

RE19.name: Auto-Refactor
RE19.definition: Systematically improve system structure without changing external behavior

RE20.name: Recursive Governance (Guardrails that Learn)
RE20.definition: Establish rules that adapt based on their own effectiveness

SY1.name: Leverage Points
SY1.definition: Identify intervention points where small changes produce disproportionate effects

SY2.name: System Boundaries
SY2.definition: Define what is inside versus outside system scope for analysis or design

SY3.name: Stocks & Flows
SY3.definition: Distinguish accumulations from rates of change affecting them

SY4.name: Requisite Variety
SY4.definition: Match control system's complexity to system being controlled

SY5.name: Systems Archetypes
SY5.definition: Recognize recurring dynamic patterns across different domains

SY6.name: Feedback Structure Mapping
SY6.definition: Diagram causal loops showing how variables influence each other

SY7.name: Path Dependence
SY7.definition: Acknowledge how early decisions constrain future options through accumulated consequences

SY8.name: Homeostasis/Dynamic Equilibrium
SY8.definition: Understand self-regulating mechanisms maintaining stable states despite disturbances

SY9.name: Phase Transitions & Tipping Points
SY9.definition: Identify thresholds where gradual changes produce sudden qualitative shifts

SY10.name: Causal Loop Diagrams
SY10.definition: Visualize circular cause-effect relationships with reinforcing and balancing dynamics

SY11.name: Governance Patterns
SY11.definition: Design decision rights, accountability structures, and coordination mechanisms

SY12.name: Protocol/Interface Standards
SY12.definition: Specify rules for interaction enabling coordination without central control

SY13.name: Incentive Architecture
SY13.definition: Design reward and penalty structures aligning individual actions with system goals

SY14.name: Risk & Resilience Engineering
SY14.definition: Build systems that fail gracefully and recover automatically

SY15.name: Multi-Scale Alignment
SY15.definition: Ensure strategy, operations, and execution cohere across organizational levels

SY16.name: Ecosystem Strategy
SY16.definition: Position organization within network of partners, competitors, and stakeholders

SY17.name: Policy Feedbacks
SY17.definition: Anticipate how rules shape behavior, which creates conditions affecting future rules

SY18.name: Measurement & Telemetry
SY18.definition: Instrument systems to capture state, changes, and anomalies for informed response

SY19.name: Meta-Model Selection
SY19.definition: Choose appropriate framework or tool for specific problem characteristics

SY20.name: Systems-of-Systems Coordination
SY20.definition: Manage interactions between independent systems with emergent behaviors
